Find a basis for \(W\). Exercise 5.16 (Artin 3.3.3) Prove that the three functions \(x^2, \cos(x)\), and \(e^x\) are linearly independent. Proof. Suppose that \[\alpha x^2+ \beta \cos(x) +\gamma e^x =0\quad \text{for all } x\in \mathbb{R}\] where \(\alpha,\beta,\gamma\) scalers. The original equation, when substitute \(x=0\) gives us \(b \cdot \cos(0) + c \cdot e^0 = 0\), which simplifies to \(b + c = 0\). Differentiating once gives \(2a \cdot x - b \cdot \sin(x) + c \cdot e^x = 0\). Substituting \(x = 0\) gives \(-b + c = 0\). Differentiating twice gives \(2a - b \cdot \cos(x) + c \cdot e^x = 0\). Substituting \(x = 0\) gives \(2a + b + c = 0\). These equations show that the only solution is \(a = b = c = 0\). Therefore, the functions \(x^2\), \(\cos(x)\), and \(e^x\) are linearly independent.
